abstract.p: Letter from Sara Schwabacher (New Visions for Public Schools) on June 14 article calls for more New York State aid to New York City schools

block.p: Our organization's experience confirms your June 14 front-page article reporting that strategically using resources aimed at improving teaching and learning has the greatest effect on student achievement.

But if the educational spending system in New York City is itself in need of reform, this does not diminish the case for equitable redistribution of New York State aid. The city school districts cited in the article as prioritizing teacher training and resource development still compare unfavorably to suburban school districts with regard to teacher salaries, proportion of certified teachers, class sizes and the ratio of students to books and computers.

Even an optimal use of New York City's current allocation of state aid will not go nearly far enough toward closing this gap.
The writer is acting president of New Visions for Public Schools.
